awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Integrated Team Science Curriculum Development & Support for the Convergence Accelerator Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the development and delivery of a novel team science curriculum for the Convergence Accelerator program. 

The Convergence Accelerator is a new effort at NSF to accelerate use-inspired convergence research in areas of national importance. The most vexing challenges require collaborative melding of expertise from different disciplines and partnership among different kinds of organizations – convergence! Essential to the Convergence Accelerator’s approach is a tailored curriculum provided to grantee teams. A crucial part of that curriculum is “Team Science.” The goal of the team science elements of the curriculum is to facilitate convergence team development and effectiveness. The funded teams are all highly interdisciplinary and incorporate expertise from different types of organizations, but in order to be effective in their projects – and truly convergent – grantee teams need to communicate and collaborate effectively and rapidly. Because Phase I Convergence Accelerator awards are only 9 months in duration, it is particularly important that teams build their communication and collaboration skills rapidly. 

This project expands upon previous successful NSF-supported work by the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI) that has resulted in TDI’s professional development tools that have been used at more than 350 workshops around the world since 2005 to help researchers enhance their capacity for collaboration within cross-disciplinary teams. It also builds upon an effective train-the-trainer workshop provided to the first cohort of Convergence Accelerator grantees. The project will extend the Toolbox Dialogue effort to create an even more comprehensive Team Science communication and collaboration curriculum. The project will facilitate development of a training effort that integrates “social-relational” as well as “cognitive-epistemic” dimensions of collaboration. The project will do this by coordinating team science curricular offerings with two other experts. The project will result in new knowledge about and methods for facilitating productive collaborative environments that is likely to foster project innovation. 

The broader impacts of this project include increasing the effectiveness of Convergence Accelerator grantee teams. By helping the teams that participate in the curriculum to rapidly identify and resolve differences, those teams will be more able to develop translational research products that positively impact the American people. The project will also develop online resources such as videos and webinars which can then be adapted to share with teams beyond the Convergence Accelerator program. Further outcomes are expected to include generalizable knowledge that will inform effective professional development in team science and convergence research broadly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “Integrated Team Science Curriculum Development & Support for the Convergence Accelerator Program” (hereafter,  “the project”) was designed to support the NSF Convergence Accelerator Program awardees in 2020 and 2021. The NSF Convergence Accelerator focuses on funding and facilitating complex, crossdisciplinary and cross-sector teams to conduct accelerated convergence research that addresses societal challenges of great consequence. Awardee cohorts are organized into thematically-focused tracks that interact during Phase I while moving quickly toward the development of convergent solutions to track-specific problems. For this grant, the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative Center (TDIC) of Michigan State University, focused on enhancing the collaborative capacity of the teams in tracks C (Quantum Technology), D (AI-Innovation Data Sharing & Modeling), E (Networked Blue Economy), and F (Trust & Authenticity in Communication Systems).  

Phase I Convergence Accelerator teams participate in an Innovation Curriculum designed to enhance their ability to conduct convergence research quickly, and this award enabled TDIC to develop and facilitate the team science portion of that curriculum for all the teams in tracks C, D, E, and F.  Our primary objectives (which we achieved) were to:

•      Coordinate the development and delivery of an integrated Team Science training program for the NSF Convergence Accelerator, and 

•      Deliver Toolbox Dialogue workshops for all Convergence Accelerator Phase I teams that could be adapted to different contexts and implemented broadly. 

We wanted to introduce teams to the challenges of cross-disciplinary (and cross-sectoral) collaboration and provide them tools and frameworks for addressing these challenges. We developed a team science curriculum for them and conducted Toolbox Dialogue workshops for each team. The most ‘hands-on’ component was the Toolbox workshops, which entailed developing customized survey-style instruments for every cohort and facilitating a structured dialogue with members of every team (2 teams per workshop for cross-pollination of ideas) around how they can improve collaborative and communicative capacity.

One of the primary aims of this work was to help convergence teams build collaborative capacity. We focused our attention on how dialogue and team science tools can help researchers transcend the academic boundary and work more effectively with people outside academia; both in private and non-profit sectors. One of the outcomes of this process was developing a more refined Toolbox survey-style instrument that is much more flexible, applicable, and better aligned with the team science literature for convergence teams. Additionally, the collaboration agreement and agreement tips tools made it easier for teams working across sectors to more effectively set expectations to again enhance the collaborative capacity critical to their success. Through working with these teams we have made these tools more generalizable, any crossdisciplinary team can use this process to improve their communication and collaborative practices, making the potential impact on other disciplines significant. It will allow teams in academia and across sectors collaborate more effectively, ultimately improving the knowledge integration necessary for tackling the grand challenges the Convergence Accelerator program is aiming to address.

Additionally, holding workshops with multiple teams over multiple years, gave us insight into our pedagogic process. It advanced understanding around how participants understand the role of dialogue in reinforcing perspective taking and team reflexivity and how we might facilitate dialogue so teams could more easily adopt these skills that will help with their collaborative process. The feedback from the sessions has allowed us to better refine and scaffold the workshops we conduct for other educational settings as well.

While the primary aim was helping teams collaborate more effectively we also advanced our scientific understanding around how real-world teams navigate collaboration and negotiate differences in service of a shared goal. The most significant contribution to this space has been the in vivo studies of these teams that contribute to the real-world study of structured dialogue on mutual understanding and team communication. This grant has helped us better understand how real team conversations emerge and take shape, and how these teams negotiate different knowledge sets, and articulate different perspectives. Hence this dataset will service as a novel contribution in the field of team science and will provide us with an understanding of team communication dynamics that are difficult to create in a laboratory setting.
